HOLLYWOOD | SILENT MOVIES

The Scandal that Almost Brought Hollywood Down

Roscoe Arbuckle mug shot

Don’t have a Medium account? You can read this story here.

Roscoe Conkling Arbuckle

Roscoe Conkling “Fatty” Arbuckle was the biggest star in Hollywood, both literally and figuratively. Weighing in at nearly 300 pounds, he was bound by contract to keep his weight up. That was in the days before GOLO.

In 1918 he signed a three-year, $3 million dollar contract with Paramount for 18 silent movies. Today the contract would be worth almost $60 million. Soon after, he signed on for another $1 million per year.

On Labor Day in 1921 Arbuckle had seven films playing in theatres across the United States. In a time when half the country plunked down their nickel for a movie ticket every week, he was on top of the world.

Then he decided to throw a party, and it all came crashing down.

Who Was “Fatty” Arbuckle?
